document: The PlayStation Vita, also known as the PS Vita or Vita, is a handheld game console developed and marketed by Sony Interactive Entertainment. Released in 2011, it served as the successor to the PlayStation Portable and competes with the Nintendo 3DS. The original model features a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, analog joysticks, and various input options. It supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G connectivity. With a quad-core CPU and GPU, the Vita offers powerful performance. Sony later introduced the PS Vita 2000 series with a smaller size, extended battery life, and an LCD screen. Additionally, they released the PlayStation TV, a re-purposed version of the Vita that works like a home video game console. The Vita's design aimed to merge the experience of dedicated gaming platforms with the emerging trend of mobile gaming.
noref_document: The PlayStation Vita, often referred to as PS Vita, was a handheld gaming console released by Sony in 2011. It featured a 5-inch OLED touch screen, front and rear cameras, and a touchpad on the back. With its powerful hardware and innovative features, the PS Vita aimed to provide a console-like gaming experience on the go. It had a diverse library of games ranging from popular franchises to indie titles, showcasing its versatility and appeal to a wide audience. Additionally, it supported online multiplayer and allowed users to connect with friends and take part in virtual communities. Despite its impressive capabilities, the PS Vita faced tough competition from smartphones and tablet devices, ultimately leading to its discontinuation in 2019.
summary:
The PlayStation Vita (PS Vita, or Vita) is a handheld game console developed and marketed by Sony Interactive Entertainment. It was first released in Japan on December 17, 2011, and in North America, Europe, and other international territories beginning on February 22, 2012. The console is the successor to the PlayStation Portable, and a part of the PlayStation brand of gaming devices; as part of the eighth generation of video game consoles, it primarily competed with the Nintendo 3DS.
The original model of the handheld includes a 5-inch (130 mm) OLED multi-touch capacitive touchscreen, two analog joysticks, and front and shoulder push-button input, and supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G. The Vita features a quad-core ARM Cortex-A9 MPCore CPU and a quad-core SGX543MP GPU. The PS Vita 2000 series, a revised version of the system, was released across 2013 and 2014. It has all of the same features with a slightly smaller size, extended battery life, and an LCD screen instead of OLED. Sony released the PlayStation TV, a short-lived, re-purposed version of the Vita that uses a television screen like a home video game console, discontinued at the end of 2015.
The Vita's design was intended to meld the experience of big-budget, dedicated video game platforms with the then up-and-coming trend of mobile gaming as seen on smart phones and tablets.

It was first released in Japan on December 17, 2011, and in North America, Europe, and other international territories beginning on February 22, 2012. The console is the successor to the PlayStation Portable, and a part of the PlayStation brand of gaming devices; as part of the eighth generation of video game consoles, it primarily competed with the Nintendo 3DS.
The original model of the handheld includes a 5-inch (130 mm) OLED multi-touch capacitive touchscreen, two analog joysticks, and front and shoulder push-button input, and supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G. The Vita features a quad-core ARM Cortex-A9 MPCore CPU and a quad-core SGX543MP GPU. The PS Vita 2000 series, a revised version of the system, was released across

document: The PlayStation Vita, also known as the PS Vita or Vita, is a handheld game console developed and marketed by Sony Interactive Entertainment. Released in 2011, it served as the successor to the PlayStation Portable and competes with the Nintendo 3DS. The original model features a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, analog joysticks, and various input options. It supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G connectivity. With a quad-core CPU and GPU, the Vita offers powerful performance. Sony later introduced the PS Vita 2000 series with a smaller size, extended battery life, and an LCD screen. Additionally, they released the PlayStation TV, a re-purposed version of the Vita that works like a home video game console. The Vita's design aimed to merge the experience of dedicated gaming platforms with the emerging trend of mobile gaming.
noref_document: The PlayStation Vita, often referred to as PS Vita, was a handheld gaming console released by Sony in 2011. It featured a 5-inch OLED touch screen, front and rear cameras, and a touchpad on the back. With its powerful hardware and innovative features, the PS Vita aimed to provide a console-like gaming experience on the go. It had a diverse library of games ranging from popular franchises to indie titles, showcasing its versatility and appeal to a wide audience. Additionally, it supported online multiplayer and allowed users to connect with friends and take part in virtual communities. Despite its impressive capabilities, the PS Vita faced tough competition from smartphones and tablet devices, ultimately leading to its discontinuation in 2019.
summary:
The PlayStation Vita (PS Vita, or Vita) is a handheld game console developed and marketed by Sony Interactive Entertainment. It was first released in Japan on December 17, 2011, and in North America, Europe, and other international territories beginning on February 22, 2012. The console is the successor to the PlayStation Portable, and a part of the PlayStation brand of gaming devices; as part of the eighth generation of video game consoles, it primarily competed with the Nintendo 3DS.
The original model of the handheld includes a 5-inch (130 mm) OLED multi-touch capacitive touchscreen, two analog joysticks, and front and shoulder push-button input, and supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G. The Vita features a quad-core ARM Cortex-A9 MPCore CPU and a quad-core SGX543MP GPU. The PS Vita 2000 series, a revised version of the system, was released across 2013 and 2014. It has all of the same features with a slightly smaller size, extended battery life, and an LCD screen instead of OLED. Sony released the PlayStation TV, a short-lived, re-purposed version of the Vita that uses a television screen like a home video game console, discontinued at the end of 2015.
The Vita's design was intended to meld the experience of big-budget, dedicated video game platforms with the then up-and-coming trend of mobile gaming as seen on smart phones and tablets.

document: Lytro, Inc., a pioneering American company founded by Ren Ng in 2006, revolutionized the world of photography with its groundbreaking light-field cameras. In February 2012, Lytro introduced its first generation pocket-sized camera, which allowed users to refocus images even after they were captured. This innovative technology garnered significant attention and generated excitement among photographers and enthusiasts alike. Building on this success, Lytro unveiled its second generation camera, the Lytro Illum, in April 2014. Targeting commercial and experimental photographers, the Lytro Illum showcased enhanced capabilities and advanced features. With a price tag of $1,600, it represented the company's commitment to pushing the boundaries of what was possible in photography.
noref_document: Lytro, a computational photography company founded in 2006 by Ren Ng, revolutionized the field with its light field camera technology. Unlike traditional cameras, which capture a single plane of light, Lytro cameras capture the entire light field, allowing users to focus the image after it has been taken. This innovative approach opened up new possibilities in photography, enabling photographers to experiment with depth of field, perspective, and post-processing adjustments. By combining hardware and software advancements, Lytro created a new way of seeing and capturing the world through its light field cameras.
summary: Lytro, Inc. was an American company founded in 2006 by Ren Ng which developed some of the first commercially available light-field cameras. Lytro began shipping its first generation pocket-sized camera, capable of refocusing images after being taken, in 8 GB and 16 GB versions on February 29, 2012. In April 2014, the company announced Lytro Illum, its second generation camera for commercial and experimental photographers. The Lytro Illum was released at $1,600.

document: The Virtual Boy, developed and manufactured by Nintendo, is a 32-bit tabletop portable video game console that was released in 1995. Marketed as the first console capable of displaying stereoscopic "3D" graphics, it revolutionized the gaming experience. By placing the head against the eyepiece, players could see a vivid red monochrome display that enhanced the visual appeal. The games utilized a remarkable parallax effect, which ingeniously created the illusion of depth. Despite the initial anticipation, sales of the Virtual Boy failed to meet expectations. Nintendo made the difficult decision to halt distribution and game development in 1996, ultimately releasing only 22 games for this groundbreaking system.
noref_document: The Virtual Boy was a portable gaming console developed and manufactured by Nintendo. Introduced in 1995, it aimed to bring a unique and immersive gaming experience through its stereoscopic 3D display. Unlike traditional gaming devices of the time, the Virtual Boy was designed to be worn on the user's head, providing a personal and isolated gaming experience. The console utilized a red monochromatic display, which created a sense of depth in games but lacked color. Despite its innovative technology, the Virtual Boy was met with mixed reviews and poor sales, leading to its discontinuation just a year after its release. Nevertheless, it remains an intriguing and somewhat overlooked piece of gaming history.
summary: The Virtual Boy is a 32-bit tabletop portable video game console developed and manufactured by Nintendo. Released in 1995, it was marketed as the first console capable of displaying stereoscopic "3D" graphics. The player uses the console like a head-mounted display, placing the head against the eyepiece to see a red monochrome display. The games use a parallax effect to create the illusion of depth. Sales failed to meet targets, and Nintendo ceased distribution and game development in 1996, having released only 22 games for the system.

document: Zune, the discontinued line of digital media products and services marketed by Microsoft, aimed to challenge and beat Apple's iPod line, which held an enormous market share at the time. In addition to a series of portable media players created in cooperation with Toshiba, Zune also offered digital media player software for Windows PCs, a music subscription service called "Zune Music Pass," and music and video streaming services for the Xbox 360 game console. Zune's offerings extended beyond the digital realm as it provided music, TV, and movie sales, as well as desktop sync software for Windows Phone. One notable partnership was with United Airlines in 2010, wherein Zune became the provider of music streaming for in-flight entertainment. However, despite its efforts and features, Zune was ultimately discontinued in June 2012.
noref_document: Zune is a digital media brand and a line of portable media players that were first introduced by Microsoft in 2006. Although the Zune player was initially a competitor to Apple's iPod, it failed to capture the same level of market success. The Zune offered unique features for its time, such as a larger screen, wireless syncing, and a unique social feature called Zune Social. It also had a subscription-based music service, Zune Pass, which allowed users to access a large library of music for a monthly fee. Despite its innovative features and design, the Zune struggled to compete with the iPod's popularity and was eventually discontinued in 2011.
summary:
Zune is a discontinued line of digital media products and services marketed by Microsoft from November 2006 until its discontinuation in June 2012. Zune consisted of a line of portable media players, digital media player software for Windows PCs, a music subscription service known as a "Zune Music Pass", music and video streaming services for the Xbox 360 game console via the Zune Software, music, TV and movie sales, and desktop sync software for Windows Phone. Zune was also the provider of music streaming for United Airlines in-flight, after a partnership in 2010.
The Zune started as a line of portable media players (PMP) created in cooperation with Toshiba. Microsoft aimed to challenge and beat Apple, whose iPod line held an enormous market share.

Zune was also the provider of music streaming for United Airlines in-flight, after a partnership in 2010.
The Zune started as a line of portable media players (PMP) created in cooperation with Toshiba. Microsoft aimed to challenge and beat Apple, whose iPod line held an enormous market share.

noref_document: Zune is a digital media brand and a line of portable media players that were first introduced by Microsoft in 2006. Although the Zune player was initially a competitor to Apple's iPod, it failed to capture the same level of market success. The Zune offered unique features for its time, such as a larger screen, wireless syncing, and a unique social feature called Zune Social. It also had a subscription-based music service, Zune Pass, which allowed users to access a large library of music for a monthly fee. Despite its innovative features and design, the Zune struggled to compete with the iPod's popularity and was eventually discontinued in 2011.

document: 3D television, also known as 3DTV, revolutionized the way viewers experienced television by providing an enhanced sense of depth perception. This technology utilized various techniques like stereoscopic display, multi-view display, and 2D-plus-depth to create a three-dimensional visual experience. Initially, most 3D TV sets used active shutter or polarized 3D systems, while some were even autostereoscopic, eliminating the need for glasses. However, as of 2017, the availability of 3D TV sets and services from manufacturers has significantly declined, indicating a shift in consumer demand and evolving technology trends.
noref_document: 3D television, a technology that has gained popularity in recent years, refers to the transmission of stereoscopic images to provide viewers with a three-dimensional visual experience. By utilizing various techniques such as polarized glasses or active shutter glasses, 3D TV allows for depth perception, immersing viewers in a more realistic and captivating environment. This innovative technology has been used in various fields including entertainment, gaming, and education, revolutionizing the way we engage with visual media. Despite its initial buzz, the adoption of 3D television has faced challenges due to high costs, the need for compatible content, and issues related to viewer discomfort. However, continuous advancements in display technology and the rise of virtual reality have contributed to the further exploration and development of 3D television, ensuring its continued presence and potential future impact in the entertainment industry.
summary:
3D television (3DTV) is television that conveys depth perception to the viewer by employing techniques such as stereoscopic display, multi-view display, 2D-plus-depth, or any other form of 3D display. Most modern 3D television sets use an active shutter 3D system or a polarized 3D system, and some are autostereoscopic without the need of glasses. As of 2017, most 3D TV sets and services are no longer available from manufacturers.


== History ==

The stereoscope was first invented by Sir Charles Wheatstone in 1838. It showed that when two pictures are viewed stereoscopically,  they are combined by the brain to produce 3D depth perception.

document: Apollo 11, the American spaceflight that successfully landed humans on the Moon, remains an iconic moment in history. In July 1969, Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin achieved this incredible feat by landing the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on the lunar surface. Armstrong emerged as the first person to step foot on the Moon, followed by Aldrin shortly after. Together, they spent over two hours venturing around Tranquility Base, the landing site they had named. During their mission, they collected a remarkable 47.5 pounds (21.5 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth. Meanwhile, pilot Michael Collins manned the Command Module Columbia, which orbited the Moon. In total, Armstrong and Aldrin spent approximately 21 hours and 36 minutes on the Moon's surface before beginning their journey back to the Command Module. The Apollo 11 spacecraft, launched by a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center in Florida, consisted of three components: a command module that returned the astronauts to Earth, a service module that provided vital support, and a lunar module with two stages for landing and ascent. The historic mission of Apollo 11 exemplified humanity's spirit of exploration and marked a significant milestone in space exploration.
noref_document: Apollo 11 was the famous space mission that landed the first humans on the Moon. Launched by NASA in 1969, Apollo 11 took an 8-day journey, commanded by Neil Armstrong. The spacecraft carried a three-person crew, including Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins. On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong became the first person to step onto the lunar surface, famously declaring, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." The mission successfully completed its objectives and returned safely to Earth, marking a significant milestone in space exploration and sparking a renewed interest in the possibilities of human space travel.
summary:
Apollo 11 (July 16–24, 1969) was the American spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 20, 1969, at 20:17 UTC, and Armstrong became the first person to step onto the Moon's surface six hours and 39 minutes later, on July 21 at 02:56 UTC. Aldrin joined him 19 minutes later, and they spent about two and a quarter hours together exploring the site they had named Tranquility Base upon landing. Armstrong and Aldrin collected 47.5 pounds (21.5 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth as pilot Michael Collins flew the Command Module Columbia in lunar orbit, and were on the Moon's surface for 21 hours, 36 minutes before lifting off to rejoin Columbia.
Apollo 11 was launched by a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center on Merritt Island, Florida, on July 16 at 13:32 UTC, and it was the fifth crewed mission of NASA's Apollo program. The Apollo spacecraft had three parts: a command module (CM) with a cabin for the three astronauts, the only part that returned to Earth; a service module (SM), which supported the command module with propulsion, electrical power, oxygen, and water; and a lunar module (LM) that had two stages—a descent stage for landing on the Moon and an ascent stage to place the astronauts back into lunar orbit.

document: The Magellan spacecraft, launched by NASA on May 4, 1989, was a robotic space probe designed to map the surface of Venus using synthetic-aperture radar technology. Weighing 1,035 kilograms (2,282 lb), it was the first interplanetary mission to be launched from the Space Shuttle and the first spacecraft to test aerobraking as a method for orbit circularization. Magellan also marked the successful resumption of U.S. interplanetary probe launches after an eleven-year hiatus. Despite early efforts to develop a budget-friendly Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar mission, Magellan emerged as a significant step in Venus exploration, providing invaluable data on the planet's surface and gravitational field.
noref_document: The Magellan spacecraft was a robotic space probe launched by NASA in 1989 to study the planet Venus. Named after the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan, this remarkable space mission was designed to map the surface of Venus using radar imaging. Magellan's high-resolution radar allowed scientists to observe Venus in unprecedented detail, unveiling vast volcanic plains, towering mountains, and immense craters. With its innovative radar system, Magellan provided crucial insights into the geological history and formation of Venus, helping scientists better understand the planet's unique characteristics and processes.
summary:
The Magellan spacecraft was a 1,035-kilogram (2,282 lb) robotic space probe launched by NASA of the United States, on May 4, 1989, to map the surface of Venus by using synthetic-aperture radar and to measure the planetary gravitational field.
The Magellan probe was the first interplanetary mission to be launched from the Space Shuttle, the first one to use the Inertial Upper Stage booster, and the first spacecraft to test aerobraking as a method for circularizing its orbit. Magellan was the fifth successful NASA mission to Venus, and it ended an eleven-year gap in U.S. interplanetary probe launches.


== History ==
Beginning in the late 1970s, scientists advocated for a radar mapping mission to Venus. They first sought to construct a spacecraft named the Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar (VOIR), but it became clear that the mission would be beyond the budget constraints during the ensuing years.

Despite early efforts to develop a budget-friendly Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar mission, Magellan emerged as a significant step in Venus exploration, providing invaluable data on the planet's surface and gravitational field.
noref_document: The Magellan spacecraft was a robotic space probe launched by NASA in 1989 to study the planet Venus. Named after the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan, this remarkable space mission was designed to map the surface of Venus using radar imaging. Magellan's high-resolution radar allowed scientists to observe Venus in unprecedented detail, unveiling vast volcanic plains, towering mountains, and immense craters. With its innovative radar system, Magellan provided crucial insights into the geological history and formation of Venus, helping scientists better understand the planet's unique characteristics and processes.
summary:

document: The year 2000 problem, also known as the Y2K problem or millennium bug, was a computer issue that arose due to the incorrect formatting and storage of calendar data for dates in and after the year 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, which meant that the year 2000 would be interpreted as 1900. This potential error had significant implications for computer-reliant industries worldwide. In the years leading up to the millennium, the general public became increasingly aware of the Y2K scare. Companies estimated that rectifying the bug would cost anywhere between $400 million and $600 billion. The lack of clarity surrounding the bug's potential dangers led some individuals to stockpile essentials, buy firearms, and withdraw large amounts of money. Despite these fears, few major errors actually occurred in 2000.
noref_document: The Year 2000 problem, also known as the Y2K bug, was a significant concern in the late 1990s leading up to the new millennium. It revolved around computer systems and software applications that represented years with only two digits, causing potential issues when the year 2000 would be interpreted as 1900 instead. Organizations worldwide embarked on extensive efforts to fix this problem before the clock struck midnight on January 1, 2000. These preparations involved debugging and updating computer systems, testing software for Y2K compatibility, and implementing contingency plans to mitigate potential disruptions. Despite initial fears of widespread chaos, the concerted global effort succeeded, and the new millennium arrived without major Y2K-related problems.
summary:
The year 2000 problem, also commonly known as the Y2K problem, Y2K scare, millennium bug, Y2K bug, Y2K glitch, Y2K error, or simply Y2K refers to potential computer errors related to the formatting and storage of calendar data for dates in and after the year 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, making the year 2000 indistinguishable from 1900. Computer systems' inability to distinguish dates correctly had the potential to bring down worldwide infrastructures for computer reliant industries.
In the years leading up to the turn of the century (millennium), the public gradually became aware of the "Y2K scare", and individual companies predicted the global damage caused by the bug would require anything between $400 million and $600 billion to rectify. A lack of clarity regarding the potential dangers of the bug led some to stock up on food, water, and firearms, purchase backup generators, and withdraw large sums of money in anticipation of a computer-induced apocalypse.Contrary to published expectations, few major errors occurred in 2000.

document: The solar eclipse of August 21, 2017, known as the "Great American Eclipse," captivated millions of people across the United States and beyond. This celestial phenomenon offered a unique opportunity for Americans to witness a total solar eclipse, as it created a remarkable path that extended from the Pacific to the Atlantic coast. Crowds gathered in cities and towns along this path to experience the awe-inspiring moment when the moon completely blocked the sun, casting a shadow over the landscape. The eclipse was not limited to the United States; it was visible from Canada's Nunavut region in the north to as far south as northern South America. Even in northwestern Europe, Africa, and northeastern Asia, people were able to catch a glimpse of this extraordinary event––their evening or morning skies graced by a partial eclipse. This historic occurrence truly brought people from around the world together to witness the magnificent beauty of our universe.
noref_document: The Solar Eclipse of August 21, 2017, also known as the "Great American Eclipse," was a remarkable celestial event that captivated millions of people across North America. This rare total solar eclipse traversed a path across the United States from the West Coast to the East Coast, providing a unique opportunity for countless skywatchers to witness the moon fully blocking the sun, creating a breathtaking display of darkness in the middle of the day. Many communities within the path of totality organized special events and viewing parties, bringing together people from all walks of life to marvel at this extraordinary cosmic phenomenon. As the first total solar eclipse visible in the contiguous United States since 1979, it sparked excitement and fascination, with professionals and amateur astronomers alike preparing to capture the event through telescopes, cameras, and special viewing glasses. Overall, the Solar Eclipse of August 21, 2017, brought together individuals from different backgrounds to share in the wonderment of our universe and served as a reminder of the awe-inspiring power of nature.
summary:
The solar eclipse of August 21, 2017, dubbed the "Great American Eclipse" by some media, was a total solar eclipse visible within a band that spanned the contiguous United States from the Pacific to the Atlantic coasts. It was also visible as a partial solar eclipse from as far north as Nunavut in northern Canada to as far south as northern South America. In northwestern Europe and Africa, it was partially visible in the late evening. In northeastern Asia, it was partially visible at sunrise.

Prior to this event, no solar eclipse had been visible across the entirety of the United States since June 8, 1918; not since the February 1979 eclipse had a total eclipse been visible from anywhere in the mainland United States.

document: The Magellan spacecraft, weighing 1,035 kilograms (2,282 lb), was an innovative robotic space probe launched by NASA on May 4, 1989, with the goal of mapping the surface of Venus by employing synthetic-aperture radar and measuring the planetary gravitational field. It holds the distinction of being the first interplanetary mission to be launched from the Space Shuttle, employing the Inertial Upper Stage booster and pioneering the use of aerobraking to circularize its orbit. Magellan successfully broke an eleven-year gap in U.S. interplanetary probe launches and marked the fifth triumphant NASA mission to Venus. Prior to its conception, scientists had initially proposed the Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar (VOIR) spacecraft, but due to budget constraints, a more feasible alternative was sought after.
noref_document: Magellan, also known as Venus Radar Mapper, was a spacecraft that was sent by NASA to explore the planet Venus. It was launched on May 4, 1989, and arrived at Venus on August 10, 1990. The main objective of the mission was to map the surface of Venus using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) to penetrate its thick atmosphere and collect data on its topography. Magellan successfully mapped 98% of Venus' surface, revealing fascinating insights into the planet's geological formations, impact craters, and volcanic structures. The mission provided scientists with valuable information about Venus' history and geologic activity, helping to enhance our understanding of Earth's closest planetary neighbor.
summary:
The Magellan spacecraft was a 1,035-kilogram (2,282 lb) robotic space probe launched by NASA of the United States, on May 4, 1989, to map the surface of Venus by using synthetic-aperture radar and to measure the planetary gravitational field.
The Magellan probe was the first interplanetary mission to be launched from the Space Shuttle, the first one to use the Inertial Upper Stage booster, and the first spacecraft to test aerobraking as a method for circularizing its orbit. Magellan was the fifth successful NASA mission to Venus, and it ended an eleven-year gap in U.S. interplanetary probe launches.


== History ==
Beginning in the late 1970s, scientists advocated for a radar mapping mission to Venus. They first sought to construct a spacecraft named the Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar (VOIR), but it became clear that the mission would be beyond the budget constraints during the ensuing years.

Magellan was the fifth successful NASA mission to Venus, and it ended an eleven-year gap in U.S. interplanetary probe launches.


== History ==
Beginning in the late 1970s, scientists advocated for a radar mapping mission to Venus. They first sought to construct a spacecraft named the Venus Orbiting Imaging Radar (VOIR), but it became clear that the mission would be beyond the budget constraints during the ensuing years.

prefix: The

document: MESSENGER, a NASA robotic space probe, successfully orbited the planet Mercury between 2011 and 2015. It conducted an extensive study of Mercury's chemical composition, geology, and magnetic field. The spacecraft's name is derived from the acronym "Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry, and Ranging," and pays homage to the messenger god Mercury from Roman mythology. MESSENGER was launched into space aboard a Delta II rocket in August 2004. Its trajectory incorporated a series of flybys, including Earth, Venus, and Mercury itself, to decelerate relative to Mercury while using minimal fuel. With its flyby of Mercury in January 2008, it became the second mission to reach the planet after Mariner 10 in 1975. Finally, MESSENGER successfully entered orbit around Mercury on March 18, 2011, marking a significant milestone as the first spacecraft to achieve such a feat.
noref_document: The MESSENGER spacecraft was a NASA mission that was aimed at studying the planet Mercury. Launched in 2004, MESSENGER was the first spacecraft to orbit Mercury and provided invaluable data about the planet's geology, surface composition, and magnetic field, among other things. During its mission, MESSENGER discovered evidence of water ice on Mercury's poles, which was a surprising finding considering the planet's proximity to the Sun. MESSENGER also observed complex geological features such as giant cliffs and volcanic plains, which gave scientists insights into the planet's history and formation. This mission significantly expanded our knowledge and understanding of Mercury and its unique characteristics.
summary:
MESSENGER was a NASA robotic space probe that orbited the planet Mercury between 2011 and 2015, studying Mercury's chemical composition, geology, and magnetic field.  The name is a backronym for "Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry, and Ranging", and a reference to the messenger god Mercury from Roman mythology.
MESSENGER was launched aboard a Delta II rocket in August 2004.  Its path involved a complex series of flybys – the spacecraft flew by Earth once, Venus twice, and Mercury itself three times, allowing it to decelerate relative to Mercury using minimal fuel. During its first flyby of Mercury in January 2008, MESSENGER became the second mission, after Mariner 10 in 1975, to reach Mercury.MESSENGER entered orbit around Mercury on March 18, 2011, becoming the first spacecraft to do so.

document: MESSENGER, a NASA robotic space probe, successfully orbited the planet Mercury between 2011 and 2015. It conducted an extensive study of Mercury's chemical composition, geology, and magnetic field. The spacecraft's name is derived from the acronym "Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry, and Ranging," and pays homage to the messenger god Mercury from Roman mythology. MESSENGER was launched into space aboard a Delta II rocket in August 2004. Its trajectory incorporated a series of flybys, including Earth, Venus, and Mercury itself, to decelerate relative to Mercury while using minimal fuel. With its flyby of Mercury in January 2008, it became the second mission to reach the planet after Mariner 10 in 1975. Finally, MESSENGER successfully entered orbit around Mercury on March 18, 2011, marking a significant milestone as the first spacecraft to achieve such a feat.
noref_document: The MESSENGER spacecraft was a NASA mission that was aimed at studying the planet Mercury. Launched in 2004, MESSENGER was the first spacecraft to orbit Mercury and provided invaluable data about the planet's geology, surface composition, and magnetic field, among other things. During its mission, MESSENGER discovered evidence of water ice on Mercury's poles, which was a surprising finding considering the planet's proximity to the Sun. MESSENGER also observed complex geological features such as giant cliffs and volcanic plains, which gave scientists insights into the planet's history and formation. This mission significantly expanded our knowledge and understanding of Mercury and its unique characteristics.

document: The 2012 phenomenon refers to a series of eschatological beliefs that foresaw cataclysmic or transformative events taking place around 21 December 2012. This specific date was considered the end of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar. To celebrate this event, festivities were held in countries associated with the Maya civilization, such as Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. The main commemorative events took place at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala. Numerous astronomical alignments and numerological formulae were proposed for this date, sparking various interpretations. Among them, a New Age perspective saw 21 December 2012 as the start of a period of positive transformation for Earth and its inhabitants, while others believed it signaled the end of the world or a similar catastrophic event. Speculations for the world's end ranged from the next solar maximum, interactions between Earth and Sagittarius A* (the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy), the Nibiru cataclysm involving a mythical planet crashing into Earth, or even the heating of Earth's core.
noref_document: The 2012 phenomenon refers to a range of beliefs and theories surrounding the end of the world or a significant global event that was predicted to occur in the year 2012. This concept gained widespread attention and discussion due to various interpretations of the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar, which marked the completion of a 5,126-year cycle on December 21, 2012. While some individuals feared a doomsday scenario or catastrophic events, others saw it as a time of spiritual transformation and consciousness awakening. Despite the excitement and anticipation leading up to the date, December 21, 2012, passed without any noteworthy apocalyptic incidents, highlighting the range of interpretations and theories associated with the 2012 phenomenon.
summary: The 2012 phenomenon was a range of eschatological beliefs that cataclysmic or transformative events would occur on or around 21 December 2012. This date was regarded as the end-date of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar, and festivities took place on 21 December 2012 to commemorate the event in the countries that were part of the Maya civilization (Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador), with main events at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala.Various astronomical alignments and numerological formulae were proposed for this date. A New Age interpretation held that the date marked the start of a period during which Earth and its inhabitants would undergo a positive physical or spiritual transformation, and that 21 December 2012 would mark the beginning of a new era. Others suggested that the date marked the end of the world or a similar catastrophe. Scenarios suggested for the end of the world included the arrival of the next solar maximum, an interaction between Earth and Sagittarius A*, a supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy, the Nibiru cataclysm in which Earth would collide with a mythical planet called Nibiru, or even the heating of Earth's core.

document: The 2012 phenomenon refers to a series of eschatological beliefs that foresaw cataclysmic or transformative events taking place around 21 December 2012. This specific date was considered the end of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar. To celebrate this event, festivities were held in countries associated with the Maya civilization, such as Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. The main commemorative events took place at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala. Numerous astronomical alignments and numerological formulae were proposed for this date, sparking various interpretations. Among them, a New Age perspective saw 21 December 2012 as the start of a period of positive transformation for Earth and its inhabitants, while others believed it signaled the end of the world or a similar catastrophic event. Speculations for the world's end ranged from the next solar maximum, interactions between Earth and Sagittarius A* (the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy), the Nibiru cataclysm involving a mythical planet crashing into Earth, or even the heating of Earth's core.
noref_document: The 2012 phenomenon refers to a range of beliefs and theories surrounding the end of the world or a significant global event that was predicted to occur in the year 2012. This concept gained widespread attention and discussion due to various interpretations of the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar, which marked the completion of a 5,126-year cycle on December 21, 2012. While some individuals feared a doomsday scenario or catastrophic events, others saw it as a time of spiritual transformation and consciousness awakening. Despite the excitement and anticipation leading up to the date, December 21, 2012, passed without any noteworthy apocalyptic incidents, highlighting the range of interpretations and theories associated with the 2012 phenomenon.
